title: 111_hr1956
content: The Act may be cited as the "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act". It allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds under Section 6402 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Upon notice from a State judicial branch or agency, the Secretary can reduce overpayments by the amount of the state judicial debt. The Secretary can reduce overpayments by the amount of a State judicial debt, pay the reduced amount to the State judicial branch or agency, and notify the person of the offset. If a joint return is involved, the notice must include both names. The Secretary can reduce overpayments to satisfy a past-due State judicial debt. If a joint return is involved, the notice must include names, taxpayer identification numbers, and addresses. The priorities for offset include reducing overpayments for internal revenue tax, past-due support, and other liabilities. The Secretary can reduce overpayments to satisfy past-due debts owed to Federal and State agencies, including support, tax obligations, and unemployment compensation debts, before crediting the overpayment towards future Federal internal revenue tax liabilities. If the Secretary receives notice from State agencies. The Secretary can apply overpayments to past-due debts owed to State agencies or State judicial branches before crediting them towards future Federal tax liabilities. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) apply for debts under this provision. The term 'past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt' refers to debts resulting from court judgments in criminal or traffic cases in the State, assessed and past-due. The term 'State judicial debt' includes court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution to crime victims resulting from court judgments in criminal or traffic cases. The Secretary will issue regulations for submitting notices of past-due debts. The Secretary will issue regulations for State judicial branches and agencies to submit notices of past-due debts, specifying required information and debt reduction procedures. Fees may be required to reimburse the Secretary for applying the procedure. The Secretary will issue regulations for State judicial branches and agencies to submit notices of past-due debts, specifying required information and debt reduction procedures. Any fees paid to the Secretary will be used to reimburse appropriations for the cost of applying the procedure. States must promptly repay any erroneous payments made by the Secretary. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is being amended to allow disclosure of certain information to agencies requesting a reduction under specific sections. Conforming amendments are made to various sections to include the new provision. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is being amended to include new provisions for reducing overpayments related to State judicial debts and Federal internal revenue tax liabilities. Amendments are made to sections 6402(d), 6402(e), and 6402(f) to reflect these changes. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is being amended to include provisions for reducing overpayments related to State judicial debts and Federal tax liabilities. The amendments made to sections 6402(d), 6402(e), and 6402(f) will apply to refunds for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008.
